description:
This small but mighty galaxy in the constellation of Octans is a collection of doubles. First, we have a double set of spiral arms that have wrapped themselves around the galaxyâ€™s central region. The central region itself is a double bar. And at both ends is a set of ansae (the bright spots plainly visible this image).

Ansae are found in the extremities of planetary ring systems and in nebulous clouds. In galaxies like NGC 7098, the ansae are areas jammed with stars. 

This is an RGB image. For an object only 4 arcminutes wide, a lot is going on! 

Tech Notes:
ASA Newtonian, 500 mm aperture, 1900mm focal length, F3.6
FLI Proline 16803, 9 mm pixel, 4096 X 4096
ASA DDM85 equatorial mount
Processing with PixInsight and Affinity Photo
title: NGC 7098, the Triple-Double Galaxy
